posts.cooked:
As a privacy-conscious user and Nostr participant, I’d love for Signal to recognize Nostr-related links such as:
• npub1…
• note1…
• nevent1…
• nostr:nevent1…
• and other valid Nostr identifiers

Currently, these are displayed as plain text, offering no interactivity. This limits usability and forces users to copy and paste into other apps, disrupting the user experience.

Feature Request:

When Signal detects a Nostr identifier or link in a message, I would like the app to:
1. Check for a registered app that can handle the nostr: scheme and open it accordingly (just like mailto: or bitcoin:).
2. If no app is registered, fallback to formatting the link using https://njump.me/ (e.g., https://njump.me/nevent1…) and:
• Display a preview thumbnail or metadata, fetched in a privacy-respecting way (as Signal does with standard links).
• Make it clickable, so users can easily view the event in a browser or their preferred client.

Why it matters:
• Nostr is growing rapidly as a decentralized communication protocol, and many of its users rely on Signal for encrypted chat.
• This change improves UX with minimal overhead and fits Signal’s commitment to openness and usability.
• Supporting recognized formats without altering Signal’s privacy model would help bridge the gap between messaging and decentralized identity/events.

Bonus: Signal could also allow power users to opt into advanced link previews for certain schemes via settings (i.e., opt-in support for nostr: previews).

Thank you for considering this feature. It would mean a lot to many users in the privacy and decentralization communities.

So the ask is for the Signal chat window to:

  • Recognize and make clickable all Nostr URIs, e.g. nostr:npub1..., nostr:nevent1..., nostr:nprofile1..., etc.

  • Also recognize and make clickable any raw Nostr bech32 strings (npub1..., note1..., nevent1..., nprofile1...), even if they aren’t already prefixed with nostr:.

  • When a user taps such a link or string, the app should:

    • Check if any app on the device is registered to handle the nostr: URI protocol.
    • If so, open the link with the system handler (allowing the user to pick or set their preferred Nostr client).
    • If not, do nothing. No functional changes to users who do not care about Nostr.

Why:

  • This would make it much easier to interact with the growing Nostr ecosystem from Signal. One paradigm-shifting app to another.
  • Many users share Nostr links and public keys in this format, and support for direct linking improves usability.
  • Major Nostr clients on iOS and Android (Damus, Amethyst, Snort, etc.) already register for the nostr: protocol.

References:

  • NIP-21: Nostr URI scheme
  • Example: nostr:npub1example... or npub1example...
  • Example: nostr:note1example... or note1example...

Suggested implementation:

  • Add pattern matching for nostr:... and bech32 Nostr prefixes.
  • Use the OS’s “open with” handler for the nostr: protocol.

Thank you for considering my idea!
